Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to provide 126 scholarships over a 5-year period for academically-talented, financially-needy students in Engineering, Computer Information Systems, Computer Aided Design and Drafting, and Robotics Technology at Baltimore City Community College (BCCC). The project builds on strong existing student support services at BCCC and develops new interventions such as invited speakers, field trips, peer tutoring, innovative mathematics workshops, engineering/technology competition and family involvement. The project includes a strong evaluation process with feedback loops to ensure continuous improvement. The mathematics-centered advising and workshops should improve mathematics skills and overall program success. Professional development opportunities will also enhance the educational benefit to the students.

The project has strong collaboration and support from local universities and industry, a commitment from industry for internships, and support from political leaders. Project partners include Morgan State University, Capitol College, Carnegie Mellon University, Lockheed Martin, Baltimore Gas & Electric, Amtek Company, and Juxtopia LLC. The demographic data support the project's objective of increasing African American enrollment in the engineering technology related programs. The project's strong advising and mentoring programs and family involvement should contribute to retention and success. The project will contribute to broadening participation of underrepresented groups and producing a highly-qualified workforce in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of the Outcomes of Award DUE-1152811

At the end of the sixth year of the BCCC S-STEM Grant DUE-1152811, the proposed goal – to increase the number of underrepresented students, especially African-Americans: (1) earning associate degrees in engineering/technology (ET); (2) transferring to four-year universities in ET majors; and (3) securing ET-related internships and job opportunities, has been achieved with the following outcomes:

Project Outcomes or Findings Addressing the Intellectual Merit

1. The project financially supported 153 ET scholars. 127 out 153 scholars successfully graduated, transferred or landed a good paying STEM internships/jobs. 26 out of 153 students dropped out of the program due to various reasons including poor academic performance, social distraction, etc.

2. Three articulation agreements between BCCC and Morgan State University (MSU) and two articulation agreements between BCCC and Capitol Technology University (CTU) are implemented during the funding period. These agreements increased the student transfer rate by 15% compared to May 2013 data.

3. Student Support/Advising Activities

Four-Year University Campus Tour/Visit – ~500 BCCC ET students participated, 80%+ provided positive feedbacks.

Field Trips to STEM Companies and Organizations – ~400 BCCC ET students participated, 90%+ provided positive feedbacks.

STEM Conferences – ~300 BCCC ET students participated, 90% of the students provided positive feedbacks.

Guest Speakers – 10 guest speakers spoke to ~800 BCCC STEM students, 77% of the students provided positive feedbacks

Four-Year School Ambassador – 200+ BCCC ET students participated, 88% of BCCC students provided positive feedbacks.

Mathematics-centered Activities – Include math awareness week, math circle friends, Just-In-Time Self-study (JiTS) increased participating student’s mathematics GPA significantly.

  • Math Awareness Week: ~950 STEM students participated, 80% of the students provided positive feedbacks.
  • Math Circle Friends: ~200 pairs of students participated. It was found that the mean math GPA of ET students who participated in the Math Circle Friends was  0.69 grade points better on 4.0 grade point system than the mean math GPA of ET students who did not participate in the Math Circle Friends.
  • JiTS: 413 BCCC STEM students participated. It was found that students (~350) with consistent JiTS participation scored 0.74 grade points better on 4.0 grade point system than students without consistent JiTS participation.

Project Outcomes or Findings Addressing Broader of Impacts

1. Recruitment effort reached out to 10,000+ Baltimore City Public School System (BCPSS) students. Exit surveys find that 33.47% of the BCPSS students are interested in attending BCCC STEM programs after graduating from the high school. The evaluation also finds via exit surveys of high school student recruitment activities at BCCC that 71.8% of participating BCPSS high school students are interested in BCCC STEM programs and 71% of the students realize the importance of mathematics in STEM careers. The project also reached out to 2,000+ BCCC developmental math students and 3,000+ BCCC general studies students. The exit surveys find that 19% of BCCC general studies students are interested in STEM majors and 20% of developmental math students are interested in STEM majors after attending ET recruitment activities.

2. Graduation, Internship, Job Placement and Transfer Students

After graduation or even before graduation, more than 80 students the project supported transferred to Johns Hopkins University, University of Maryland College Park, University of Maryland Baltimore County, Morgan State University, Capitol Technology University, Towson University, and many out of state universities.

More than 50 students the project supported successfully completed prestigious STEM internships during the funding period. Some most recent highlights are as follows:

  • One BCCC ET Scholar successfully completed Johns Hopkins Research Experience for Undergraduates in Computational; Sensing and Medical Robotics 2018 Summer Internship Program.
  • One BCCC ET Scholar successfully completed 2018 Summer Internship Program at Johns Hopkins University Talent Acquisition Department.
  • One BCCC ET Scholar successfully completed the internship of 2018 NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site program on Smart UAVs at Auburn University, Auburn, Alabama.
  • Six (6) BCCC ET Scholars successfully completed NASA Goddard Space Flight Center 2018 Summer Internship.

The project team helped more than twenty (20) ET scholars find good full time engineering related jobs at various STEM companies through BCCC/Employer Partnership developed in the S-STEM project.

3. Community Outreach Effort includes BCCC STEM community Day, in-city recruitment activities, sponsoring BCPSS Robotics team, serving as STEM advisory board member at local community centers, etc.

4.      Faculty/Staff Professional Development

The project sponsored or help sponsored two professional development activities for BCCC faculty and staff.

5.      Institutional resources that form infrastructure

N/A


Last Modified: 11/07/2018
Modified by: Yun Liu
